Trial_Design.evidence: The left knee was randomized to receive either standard three-layer closure with staples or the same closure supplemented with tissue adhesive with the opposite treatment used on the contralateral knee.

Participants.evidence: Thirty patients undergoing simultaneous bilateral TKA were included in the study.

Intervention.evidence: The left knee was randomized to receive either standard three-layer closure with staples or the same closure supplemented with tissue adhesive with the opposite treatment used on the contralateral knee.

Objective.evidence: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of wound closure using a high-viscosity tissue adhesive in simultaneous bilateral TKA with respect to (1) postoperative wound drainage, measured as number of dressing changes in the first 72 hours postoperatively; and (2) wound healing assessed using the ASEPSIS score.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Postoperative wound drainage was evaluated as drainage resulting in a dressing change. The number of dressing changes during the first 72 hours postoperatively was recorded.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The left knee was randomized to receive either standard three-layer closure with staples or the same closure supplemented with tissue adhesive with the opposite treatment used on the contralateral knee.

Blinding.evidence: The nurses changing the dressing were blinded to treatment allocation up to the first dressing change.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty patients undergoing simultaneous bilateral TKA were included in the study.

Number_Analysed.evidence: One patient underwent a constrained TKA and underwent revision 2 days after the index procedure and was therefore excluded leaving 29 patients (58 knees) for analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Knees with tissue adhesive underwent fewer dressing changes (median, 0; interquartile range [IQR], 0-1) compared with the contralateral knee (IQR, 1-2; difference of medians, one dressing change; p = 0.001).
